abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Forestry Sector
            Project for Cote d'Ivoire was satisfactory. The project
            achieved most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was substantial, sustainability is uncertain,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, project objectives and implementation
            responsibilities need to be as specific as possible. Also,
            project design should be flexible enough to allow
            adjustments if and when required. Second, project monitoring
            and evaluation should critically review the work program of
            the implementing agencies to ensure its focus on the
            achievement of long term objectives while keeping tight
            control over the program of work and financial performance
            at the same time. Finally, protection and management of
            natural forests, including resettlement of illegal settlers,
            is a long term process of considerable socio-economic
            complexity, requiring mutual understanding of the
            prerogatives of the various parties involved, including
            policy makers, implementing agencies, and the affected
            population. In order to be sustainable, action programs have
            to be based on negotiated terms agreed upon by all
            stakeholders, including the private sector, and supported by
            adequate measures to create a favorable incentive framework.
